title-group.article-title: Mandibular distraction osteogenesis for mandibular retrognathism caused by malunion of bilateral mandibular condyle fractures in childhood with temporomandibular joint dislocation: a case report

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Kyoto Oral Health Care Center, Rakuwakai Otowa Hospital, Kyoto, Japan
2Kyoto Jaw Deformity Center, Rakuwakai Otowa Hospital, Kyoto, Japan
3Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Nara Medical University, Kashihara, Japan

author-notes.corresp: Yosuke Kobayashi, Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Kyoto Oral Health Care Center, Rakuwakai Otowa Hospital, 2 Otowa Chinji-cho, Yamashina-ku, Kyoto 607-8062, Japan, TEL: +81-75-593-4111, E-mail: kobayashi-yosuke@rakuwa.or.jp, ORCID: https://orcid.org/0009-0004-3106-6763

abstract.p: Untreated mandibular condyle fractures in childhood can result in significant jaw deformities, such as mandibular retrognathism, open bite, and facial asymmetry, which may necessitate surgical intervention in later years. Surgical approaches vary depending on the severity of the condition, including mandibular surgery alone, maxillomandibular surgery, or mandibular distraction osteogenesis (MDO). This report highlights a case involving mandibular retrognathism and open bite with condylar dislocation and malunion caused by untreated pediatric condyle fractures. Key challenges in this case included excessive anterior mandibular movement, irregular morphology of the mandibular ramus caused by malunion from fracture healing, and anteromedial dislocation of both condyles, all of which posed significant surgical complexities. The surgical approach combined Le Fort I osteotomy with MDO to perform maxillary impaction and mandibular advancement, followed by a secondary genioplasty. Notably, the dislocated temporomandibular joints were left untreated. Two years postoperatively, no relapse or recurrence of open bite was observed, and the dislocated condyles showed no positional and morphological changes, reflecting favorable outcomes. To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of orthognathic surgery combined with MDO for bilateral dislocated mandibular condyles, making it a valuable contribution to clinical practice.

sec.title: I. Introduction
sec.p: In the treatment of pediatric mandibular condyle fractures, conservative treatment is given greater preference compared to adult cases. Considering the healing process of mandibular condyle fractures and subsequent impacts on mandibular development, careful consideration should be given when determining the treatment plan. Conservative treatment for pediatric mandibular condyle fractures usually leads to good outcomes with little or no functional or morphological disorders, due to the rapid and vigorous bone remodeling1,2. However, mandibular condyle fractures that pass untreated in infancy can lead to jaw deformities such as mandibular retrognathia, open bite, and facial asymmetry, in some cases necessitating orthognathic surgery1. According to Rowe3, condylar fracture occurring before 3 years of age showed a greater risk of severe asymmetric deformity. In such cases, mandibular advancement by sagittal split ramus osteotomy (SSRO) may be indicated. However, postoperative relapse and progressive condylar resorption are concerns for cases with ≥6 mm of mandibular advancement or counterclockwise mandibular rotation4. Postoperative relapse is often caused by excessive stretching of the medial pterygoid muscle, masseter muscle, and peri-mandibular soft tissue, and overloading of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ), including the condyle4-6. To address these problems, two-jaw surgery or mandibular distraction osteogenesis (MDO) should be considered. In two-jaw surgery, impaction of the maxilla leads to auto-rotation of the mandible (counterclockwise rotation), which reduces stretching in muscles attached to the mandible during the advancement of the mandible. In MDO, gradual extension of the mandible is expected to result in osteogenesis in the extended area and stretching of surrounding soft tissues. In the malunion of condyle or ramus fractures, surgical procedures on the same site may be difficult due to the tortuous bone morphology. Especially in SSRO, the dissection and elevation of the internal periosteum of the ramus is an important part of the process. It is important to evaluate the mandibular morphology and TMJ and consider the mandibular surgical technique preoperatively. Patients with mandibular condyle fractures may present with dislocated and deviated mandibular condyles if not properly restored. In orthognathic surgery for such cases, the need for evaluation of TMJ and preoperative procedures, such as open reduction and fixation or artificial TMJ replacement, must be considered. However, to the best of our knowledge, there have been no studies or reports on jaw deformities involving bilateral TMJ dislocation. We had the opportunity to treat a patient with mandibular retrognathism caused by malunion of bilateral mandibular condyle fractures in childhood with TMJ dislocation. Good facial profile and occlusion were obtained using orthognathic surgery combined with MDO. This case report is valuable because, to the best of our knowledge, no reports have described orthognathic surgery combined with MDO applied to mandibular retrognathism with bilateral malunions and dislocations of the TMJs following bilateral mandibular condyle fractures.

sec.title: II. Case Report
sec.p: A 19-year-old woman was referred to our facility with a chief complaint of retrognathia, facial asymmetry, and anterior open bite. At 3 years old, the patient had suffered severe damage to the mandible due to an automobile accident, but medical attention had not been sought and she was left without evaluation of the maxilla, mandible or occlusion. Anterior open bite was subsequently diagnosed during a school dental health examination and a visit to an orthodontic clinic at 12 years old. Jaw deformity was diagnosed and she was referred to our institution for orthognathic surgery. On clinical examination, extraoral findings included retrognathia, severe micrognathia, left deviation of the chin and lip incompetence.(Fig. 1. A, 1. B) No tenderness, clicks or noises were noted in the TMJs, and maximum mouth opening was 35.0 mm. Intraoral findings included –5.0 mm of overbite, +5.0 mm of overjet, and anterior open bite.(Fig. 1. C) Pantomography revealed bilateral mandibular condyle atrophy and anterior deviation of both condyles from the mandibular fossae.(Fig. 1. D) Lateral cephalogram showed vertical maxillary excess, shortening of the mandibular rami, clockwise rotation of the mandible, severe mandibular retrusion, condylar dislocations, anterior open bite, and upper airway constriction.(Fig. 2. A) Frontal cephalogram showed occlusal cant and left deviation of the chin.(Fig. 2. B) Computed tomography (CT) showed bilateral malunion of the condylar necks after condylar fractures and anterior and medial condylar dislocations from the mandibular fossae.(Fig. 3) In addition, the inner surfaces of bilateral rami displayed severely bumpy morphologies due to the malunion of the condylar fractures.(Fig. 4) Skeletal mandibular retrognathism caused by malunion of bilateral mandibular condyle fractures with TMJ dislocation, vertical maxillary excess, facial asymmetry and open bite were diagnosed. We planned orthodontic treatment and two-jaw surgery, in which the maxilla would be impacted and the occlusal cant corrected by Le Fort I osteotomy, and the mandible extended and advanced by MDO following mandibular counterclockwise rotation. After completing preoperative orthodontic treatment, Le Fort I osteotomy and MDO were performed under general anesthesia. An internal distractor (Zurich Pediatric Ramus Cloverleaf design; KLS Martin) was used in the MDO. Surgical simulation was performed using a three-dimensional (3D) model of the skull created from preoperative CT data to determine the setting site and direction of extension for the distractor, then the distractor was bent preoperatively. Osteotomy of the mandibular body was performed posteriorly at the second molar on both sides, and the distractor was fixed with three 5-mm screws on the proximal side in each plate hole and with a 13-mm screw on the distal side.(Fig. 5) After a 7-day latency period, the distraction devices were activated at a rate of 0.5 mm twice per day (total, 1.0 mm). Intermaxillary traction on the anterior teeth by intermaxillary elastics was performed to prevent anterior open bite following forward extension of the mandible. Mandibular distraction was completed when the intercuspal position was obtained. Total mandibular extension was 10.5 mm on the right side and 17.0 mm on the left side. The progress was good, but some chin retrusion and muscle strain on the mentalis muscle remained. At 1 year postoperatively, the metal plates and screws fixing the maxilla and mandibular distractor were removed and genioplasty was performed under general anesthesia. In the genioplasty, the bone fragment was moved 8.0 mm anteriorly and 1.0 mm superiorly and fixed with absorbable plates and screws (Super FIXSORB MX; Teijin Medical Technologies). As of 2 years since the initial surgery was performed and 1 year since completion of the secondary surgery, good progress has been made. The frontal aspect appears symmetrical and the marked retraction of the chin has improved in the lateral aspect.(Fig. 6. A-6. D) No tenderness, clicks or noises were noted in the TMJ, and maximum mouth opening was 30.0 mm. Intraoral findings showed +1.0 mm of overbite, +1.5 mm of overjet, and no evidence of anterior open bite.(Fig. 6. E) CT revealed no bone resorption and no changes in the position of condyle-like structures compared to preoperatively.(Fig. 7) The cephalometric comparison and superimposition of profilograms from three time points (pre-MDO, pre-genioplasty and at 2-year follow-up after MDO; Table 1, Fig. 8) revealed increasing chin prominence, a decrease in the nasolabial angle, improvement of the mesiofacial height-to-lower facial height ratio, and correction of the E-line.

sec.title: III. Discussion
sec.p: Conservative treatment is typically preferred for mandibular condyle fractures in children, as some studies have demonstrated a successful healing process through bone remodeling7-9. Other reports have suggested that surgical interventions may negatively affect the primary growth centers of mandibular condylar cartilage, potentially leading to TMJ disorders postoperatively10. In addition, rapid resorption of the displaced mandibular condyle and new bone formation and regeneration of the mandibular condyle at the fracture site have been observed in cases of mandibular condyle fractures with medial dislocation in children11,12. Demianczuk et al.13 investigated the effect of pediatric mandibular fracture on facial growth. That study showed that patients injured during a mandibular growth spurt tended to require subsequent orthognathic surgery, while patients younger than 4 years or older than 12 years typically required no orthognathic surgery, although orthodontic treatment was sometimes necessary. In the present case, the fractured mandibular condyles were thought to be atrophied with insufficient bone remodeling due to unstable mandibular positions without proper occlusal guidance, resulting in jaw deformity. Regardless of the treatment approach chosen, proper occlusal guidance and routine evaluation of the TMJs with radiographs and CT are considered essential to avoid the development of malocclusion, TMJ disorder and jaw deformity.

In orthognathic surgery for retrognathia with anterior open bite, counterclockwise rotation and advancement of the mandible with maxillary impaction is often performed in two-jaw surgery. A one-stage approach of mandibular advancement by SSRO or inverted L ramus osteotomy and Le Fort I osteotomy was initially planned in the present case. However, preoperative simulation revealed a need for 15 mm of mandibular advancement. Joss and Vassalli4 reported that postoperative stability was poor with ≥6 mm of mandibular advancement. Similarly, Ow and Cheung14 reported that SSRO showed good stability for advancements less than 6 mm, whereas advancements greater than 6 mm were associated with a higher incidence of relapse. In addition to the problem of the amount of mandibular advancement, preoperative CT revealed markedly uneven morphologies of the inner surfaces of the mandibular rami due to malunion of the mandibular condyle fractures. Detachment and elevation of soft tissues up to the posterior ramus of the mandible on the markedly uneven morphology were predicted to be extremely difficult. Based on these findings, MDO with the osteotomy line set from distal to the second molar to anterior to the mandibular angle was selected so that the inner surfaces of the mandibular rami were not included in the operative field. Two devices can be used for MDO: external and internal distractors. Placement of an external distractor such as the rigid external distraction (RED) system allows adaptation of the distraction vector throughout the distraction period. On the other hand, use of an internal distractor for distraction osteogenesis reduces both physical and psychological stresses on the patient and shortens the length of hospitalization15-18. However, since the direction of extension is linear with internal distractors, anterior open bite may occur after mandibular distraction. The setting of the distraction vector significantly affects treatment outcomes, and an inappropriate distraction vector may lead to undesirable mandibular position or excessive loading on the TMJ. Dolanmaz et al.19 have stated that accurate placement of the distractors and determining the correct distraction vector are crucial factors that have an influence on long term clinical success. In the present case, the placement of the distracters was carefully determined using preoperative simulation with a 3D model, and the distraction vector was meticulously planned using CT-based simulation. We performed model surgery using plaster and 3D models, setting the distraction vector parallel to the occlusal plane. Then we preoperatively test-fitted the distractors setting the distraction vector parallel to the occlusal plane on the 3D model. Furthermore, in the present case, the target occlusion was able to be achieved by providing mobility to the proximal bone fragments with 1 mono-cortical screw replaced in the distal bone fragments worked as a pivot20 and traction on the anterior teeth by intermaxillary elastics during MDO. The necessity of TMJ intervention prior to orthognathic surgery in patients with jaw deformities and dislocated mandibular condyles is still controversial. Open reduction and internal fixation or total TMJ replacement (TMJR) were considered indicated for the obsolete mandibular condyle fracture with TMJ dislocation. However, repositioning of the dislocated mandibular condyle into the mandibular fossa was difficult at more than 15 years after the causative injury. Also, there were concerns of future revision surgery due to fracture of the prosthesis in TMJR for young patients. Based on the above considerations, MDO was applied without the procedure for TMJ in the present case. MDO is believed to have the effect of reducing the excessive loading on the TMJ (including the mandibular condyle) through gradual lengthening of the osteotomy site and soft tissue expansion. However, the risk of relapse should be considered in long-term observation. There is concern about bone resorption in the anterior part of the mandibular condyle by MDO. This is because the mandibular condyle rotates clockwise and receives compression in the anterior portion within the mandibular fossa, when the mandibular body is extended anteriorly by MDO. In the present case, the comparison of pre- and postoperative CT images showed no bony resorption on the dislocated mandibular condyles. It is presumed that the anterior dislocation of the mandibular condyle avoided excessive pressure because there was no hard tissue in front of the mandibular condyle. Dolanmaz et al.19 concluded that long-term relapse following MDO remains within acceptable limits. Good progress has been made with no changes in range of mouth opening, no TMJ symptoms and no evidence of relapse of mandibular retrusion or anterior open bite. This is the first case report of the orthognathic surgery with MDO was applied to a patient with jaw deformities and bilateral dislocated mandibular condyles, resulting in favorable outcomes. However, careful follow-up is needed to ensure no changes occur in the dislocated mandibular condyles, since only 2 years has passed since the initial surgery.

fn.p: Y.K. analyzed the patient data and wrote the manuscript. H.O. and Y.Y. carefully reviewed and revised the manuscript. All authors read and approved the final manuscript.

p.bold: Ethics Approval and Consent to Participate

fn.p: All procedures followed were in accordance with the ethical standards of the responsible committee on human experimentation (Rakuwakai Otowa Hospital and national) and with the 1964 Declaration of Helsinki and later versions. Informed consent was obtained from the patient before the procedure.
Written consent was obtained from the patient for use and publication of clinical images.
No potential conflict of interest relevant to this article was reported.

caption.p: Preoperative findings. A. Frontal appearance. B. Lateral appearance. C. Intraoral examination. D. Pantomography.

Preoperative lateral and frontal cephalograms. A. The lateral cephalogram shows vertical maxillary excess, shortening of the mandibular ramus, clockwise rotation of the mandible, severe mandibular retrusion, condylar dislocation, anterior open bite, and upper airway constriction. B. The frontal cephalogram shows occlusal cant and left deviation of the chin.

Preoperative CT of bilateral mandibles. CT shows malunion of bilateral mandibular condyle fractures with temporomandibular joint dislocation. Bilateral mandibular condyles lie anteromedially. The inner surfaces of bilateral rami display markedly uneven morphologies. A. Right TMJ (sagittal section). B. Left TMJ (sagittal section). C. TMJ (coronal section). D. Right TMJ (3D model). The arrow indicates the mandibular condyle. The zygomatic arch has been cut to show the mandibular condyle. E. Left TMJ (3D model). The arrow indicates the mandibular condyle. The zygomatic arch has been cut to show the mandibular condyle. (CT: computed tomography, TMJ: temporomandibular joint, 3D: three-dimensional)

Inner surfaces of bilateral rami (three-dimensional model). The inner surfaces of bilateral rami displayed severely bumpy morphologies due to the malunion of the condylar fractures. A. Right. B. Left.
Postoperative facial and intraoral photographs and cephalograms. A, B. Lateral and frontal profiles. C, D. Lateral and frontal cephalograms. E. Intraoral photograph.
Internal distractor. Three 5-mm screws are used on the proximal side along with a 13-mm screw on the distal side.

Postoperative CT of bilateral mandible condyles. No bone resorption or changes in positions of condyle-like structures are observed compared to the preoperative condition. A. Right TMJ (sagittal section). B. Left TMJ (sagittal section). C. TMJ (coronal section). D. Right TMJ (3D model). The arrow indicates the mandibular condyle. The zygomatic arch has been cut to show the mandibular condyle. E. Left TMJ (3D model). The arrow indicates the mandibular condyle. The zygomatic arch has been cut to show the mandibular condyle. (CT: computed tomography, TMJ: temporomandibular joint, 3D: three-dimensional)

Superimposition of cephalometry from three time points: pre-MDO, pre-genioplasty and at 2-year follow-up after MDO. Increasing chin prominence, distraction of the mandible, decreased nasolabial angle, improved mesiofacial height-to-lower facial height ratio, and correction of the E-line are evident. (MDO: mandibular distraction osteogenesis)

fn.p: (SNA: sella nasion point A, SNB: sella nasion point B, ANB: A point nasion B point, ANS-Me: anterior nasal spine-menton, MDO: mandibular distraction osteogenesis)
